posts.name: Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana
posts.note: Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana is a casual local pizzeria chain serving a menu of coal-fired pies, beer, and wine since 1925. Oder the clam pizza along with original cheese and sauce. From the Eater website, 'If you've never had New Haven-style pizza, the thing to know about it is that the people who still make it have been making it for a very long time. They call it apizza, which is pronounced roughly, a-beets — from an old dialect once found among descendants of immigrants from the Amalfi coast circa the early 20th century — and they guard their recipes like family secrets. Frank Pepe, born in the town of Maiori just southwest of Naples, was one of those immigrants.'

posts.name: LC Cash and Carry
posts.note: From their website, ‘LC Cash and Carry, also known as LC Fine Food, is an establishment steeped in history, founded by the late and great Italo “Leo” Ciocca in the year 1965. Leo’s vision was to offer the finest Italian imports to his esteemed clientele. With his unwavering commitment to excellence and his unbridled passion for the food industry, Leo expanded his business, reaching new heights of success while simultaneously adding new products and acquiring new customers across the wholesale and retail sectors. Today, his legacy lives on through LC Cash and Carry, where the tradition of offering authentic Italian products still remains strong while at the same time embracing the evolution of the market by adding a vast assortment of domestic products to cater to a wider audience.’ Frank recommends ordering some of their cheese.

posts.name: The Port of Call
posts.note: From their website, ‘The Port of Call is a nautical-themed cocktail lounge and restaurant. The Port of Call hearkens back to the days of maritime excursions, exploring international cocktail culture and cuisine together, port by port. Voted one of the 24 Best Bars in America by Esquire magazine. Downstairs, you’ll find a laid-back pub serving beer and bar bites, complete with a shuffleboard table and arcade games. In the upper salon, enjoy a cocktail-driven dinner experience drawing from port cities near and far.’ From the Boston Eater website, ‘As evening arrives and you start to get thirsty, head to the Port of Call. Pick your vibe at two separate bars in the space: Upstairs offers the timeless elegance of a captain’s quarters, with light filtering through red velvet curtains across warm wood paneling and onto the centerpiece, a majestic curved bar made from salvaged ship wood. Downstairs at Dive Bar, there’s neon signage, a vinyl record collection, vintage games, a photo booth, and a diving suit in the corner. While Dive focuses on cold beer and simple cocktail builds, Port of Call’s upstairs drink list, led by director Jade Ayala, is more complex and tropical. On both levels, find the same top-notch food menu created by 2023 James Beard nominee Reneé Touponce, who works magic with cured local fish in particular. Order the bacalaitos — a golden, Puerto Rican salted fluke fritter served with ephemeral cilantro lime foam — tender adobo-marinated beef tongue, and a snappy smoked hot dog dressed with bonito aioli and kimchi in a light and tangy double-fermented bao bun. The Port of Call also hosts performances almost every night, from sultry jazz to disco drag shows; it’s a lively draw for visitors and locals alike.’ Brad recommends ordering the beef empanadas.

posts.name: Rawley's Drive-In
posts.note: From the Food Network ‘On The Best Thing I Ever Ate: Fried, Alex calls Rawley’s Drive-In her place for a deep-fried meal. Rawley’s signature deep-fried hot dogs have a long-standing fan base, too. For the ultimate bite, get “The Works,” which Alex says includes the perfect duo of fried foods: bacon and hot dogs.’ They recommend ordering the Deep Fried Hot Dog and fries. Titus tweeted the following about Rawley’s Drive-In, ‘The Chili Cheese Dog at Rawley’s Drive-In (Fairfield, CT). A natural casing Hummel Bros wiener (beef/pork) is fried, then crisped on a hot flattop. It goes into a toasted split-top roll with a slice of White American cheese sitting underneath. Add onions. Since 1947.’

posts.name: Stowe's Seafood
posts.note: From their website, ‘When hard times hit during the Depression, grandfather Stowe went to work driving a truck for Bilco on Bay View Place. The little business eventually grew into a market, then a full-blown restaurant called Stowe’s Pilot House, which was a regional favorite clear into the 1970s. A classic seafood shack across from the West Haven Beach has a simple menu of fresh fish, fried New England style, plus perfect lobster rolls, all served in paper boats!’ Frank recommends ordering the fried seafood.
